story:
Help Bring a Piece of History Back to Life

The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History, a Smithsonian affiliated, non-profit Museum located in Albuquerque, New Mexico, is restoring its B-52B Stratofortress, serial number 52-0013.  She is one of only four B-models in the world on display for public viewing, the first to air drop a hydrogen bomb and the only B-52B left in existence that has dropped atomic weapons - all during testing.

This enormous restoration initiative is a special project within Operation Preservation, an ongoing campaign to repaint and refurbish the iconic aircraft in the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History’s nine-acre outdoor exhibit area, Heritage Park.

Our Museum's iconic B-52B has experienced the ravages of the southwestern weather, and we would like to ask for your support in paying for the surface preparation and painting of the exterior of the aircraft (a surface area of over 2/3 of an acre). By helping with this behemoth endeavor, your support will:

  • Celebrate the men and women who designed, built, maintained and flew every B-52 model since the 1950s to today's recent models.
  • Educate all generations on the historical significance of the B-52B Stratofortress.
  • Connect Museum visitors with an important part of America's history and provide them with an opportunity to experience a B-52B up close.

The total B-52B restoration cost is expected to be $120,000. Approximately 1/2 of this cost will be paid by this Indiegogo project. The money raised in this campaign will be used for the cosmetic restoration of the fuselage and wings. That is, to purchase the paint ($460) per gallon and primer ($300 per gallon), prepare the airplane's surface and then paint the fuselage and wings. This will also include painting the "Air Force Special Weapons Center" insignia on the starboard side and the "Air Force Systems Command" on the port side. To learn more about the B-52B surface area calculations and the cost of the paint for this project, please click here. 

If we exceed our campaign goal, we will work to add wheel-chair accessible pathways around the aircraft as well as lighting that will truly bring the airplane to life. In the instance we do not reach our entire goal of $60,000 with this campaign, Museum staff and volunteers will continue to push forward on the restoration. Painting an airplane of this size requires multiple work phases - including preparing the aircraft for paint, application of primer and application of paint - and we would focus on the phases that required less labor costs until sufficient funds are raised.

With a quickly approaching target completion date for the B-52B restoration of August, 2016, we ask that you please consider becoming a member of the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History's B-52B Restoration Team by making a donation through Indiegogo! As a part of the B-52B support team, you will personally help in the preservation of this iconic aircraft.



About Our B-52B Stratofortress 

The B-52 Stratofortress is a long-range, subsonic, jet-powered strategic bomber. Built by Boeing – with a wingspan of 185 ft and weighing 420,000 lbs – B-52 airplanes have been operated by the United States Air Force since the 1950s and the more recent models are expected to serve continuously into the future. 

The first B-52B  - one of only 50 ever made - was delivered to the Strategic Air Command (SAC) in June of 1955, and the B-model was the first in the B-52 series to actually serve with operational bomb wings in the Strategic Air Command. Over the years, the aircraft has proved itself in combat and peace time readiness. The B-52B – the type of aircraft located at the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History – was the first truly operational version of the Stratofortress that featured an enhanced reconnaissance capability and was fitted with a bombing/navigation system, and they remained in service into the mid-1960s when they were traded in for more modern B-52s.  

“Our B-52 at the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History is truly Albuquerque’s airplane,” said Jim Walther, Museum Director. “This airplane was delivered directly from Boeing to Kirtland in 1955, assigned to the Special Weapons Center at Kirtland Air Force Base, and it was never assigned to another Air Force base.”

The B-52B as it was displayed at the Museum when it was formerly known as the National Atomic Museum and was formerly located on Kirtland Air Force Base (1971-2001).

On April 29, 1955, Kirtland Air Force Base (KAFB) received its first B-52B Stratofortress (our B-52B), s/n 52-0013. Major Jerome L. Blanchard accepted delivery of the aircraft at the Boeing Plant in Seattle and piloted the aircraft to KAFB. All crew members were from the 4925th Test Group.

The aircraft was among the first ten B-52Bs delivered to the Air Force. “Old 013” was assigned to the Air Force Special Weapons Center at Kirtland Air Force Base. Our B-52B conducted many drop tests of inert weapon shapes to explore weapons separation characteristics at release and to gather ballistics data.

The aircraft participated in the Redwing Cherokee test, near the Bikini Atoll.  On May 21, 1956, it became the first B-52 to drop a live nuclear device and the first aircraft to drop a hydrogen bomb. Our B-52B  also participated in Operation Dominic which took place from April until November 1962. Operation Dominic saw the last atmospheric tests, including air drops of nuclear devices. In its years of service, B-52B, s/n 52-0013, dropped over one dozen live nuclear devices in various operations.

When the Limited Nuclear Test Ban treaty was signed in 1963, Albuquerque’s B-52B, s/n 52-0013, was removed from the roster and was later delivered to the Museum, formerly known as the National Atomic Museum, in 1971.

The B-52B Stratofortress:

  • Armament: Two 20mm Cannons, 43,000 lbs. of bombs.
  • Engines: EightPratt & Whitney J57-P-1W
  • Maximum Speed: 630 mph at 20,000 ft.
  • Cruising Speed: 525 mph
  • Range: 3,600 miles at combat weight. 7, 350 miles maximum ferry range.
  • Service Ceiling: 47,000 ft. at combat weight.
  • Span: 185 ft.
  • Length: 156 ft. 7 in.
  • Weight: 420,000 lbs. gross
  • Crew: Six to eight depending on mission.
  • Source: National Museum of the United States Air Force.

Aerial view of B-52B Stratofortress, s/n 52-0013.

Our B-52B when it was assigned on May 21, 1956, to the Air Force Special Weapons Center for Operation Redwing (Cherokee) / TX-15-X1 Hydrogen Bomb test - Fred Island Air Force Base.

Our B-52B was briefly renamed Deterrent I for the Dominic series of nuclear tests in the Pacific in 1962. Shown here with a SAC crew from Sheppard Air Force Base, it had flown to the Pacific for the test series with a crew from Kirtland Air Force Base, which also participated in the tests, as did scientists from Sandia Corporation, the name at that time for Sandia National Laboratories.


Who We Are

The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History is a Smithsonian Affiliate and is the nation's only congressionally chartered museum in its field. The Museum is nationally accredited though the American Alliance of Museum and is also a member of the Association of Science-Technology Centers. The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization.

The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History was established in 1969 as an intriguing place to learn the story of the Atomic Age, from early research of nuclear development through today’s peaceful uses of nuclear technology. The Museum strives to present, through permanent and changing exhibits and displays, the diverse applications of nuclear energy in the past, present and future along with the stories of the field’s pioneers.

This 30,000-sq-ft building and nine-acre outdoor exhibit area display artifacts from Geiger counters, historic medical devices and items from the Manhattan Project to vintage comic books, nostalgic toys and a B-29 Superfortress. The major interior exhibits include Nano, Pioneers of the Atom, Trinity and its Legacy, Hiroshima and Nagasaki, the Cold War, Energy Encounter, Nuclear Medicine, Radiation 101 and more. The Museum also hosts Little Albert’s Lab, an area where young, inquisitive minds can explore hands-on science activities.

Heritage Park, the Museum’s nine-acre outdoor exhibit area, is one of the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History’s most popular attractions. With its B-52B Stratofortress, B-29 Superfortress, B-47 Stratojet, F-105D Thunderchief, A-7 Corsair II and F-16 Fighting Falcon, the Museum’s collection is the largest aircraft collection for public viewing in the state of New Mexico.

The Museum’s mission is “to serve as America’s resource for nuclear history and science. The Museum presents exhibits and quality educational programs that convey the diversity of individuals and events that shape the historical and technical context of the nuclear age.” It is truly a place to learn, to imagine, to think and to draw your own conclusions.



Our Success Stories


Our Museum's B-29 Superfortress before restoration.

Our Museum's B-29 Superfortress after restoration.
The most current example of the Museum’s aircraft restoration work can be seen in last year’s Operation Preservation project that involved rescuing our B-29 Superfortress, one of only 17 complete aircraft of its kind left in existence.

Restoration of the B-29 began in April of 2015 under the supervision of Restoration Project Coordinator, Major Jerry Hanks, USMC (Retired), with help from Museum staff and volunteers and was funded by donations received from supporters and entities with personal ties to the Museum and the historic aircraft. The Museum also successfully raised over $44,000 through a Kickstarter campaign to pay for paint and primer.

Restoration included the B-29 receiving a new coat of primer and paint, bodywork to the aircraft, new cockpit windows and the vintage 509th Wing of the Strategic Air Command paint and trim. 

The Museum held a dedication ceremony on Tuesday, August 11, 2015, where dignitaries were present to publicly acknowledge the legacy and historical significance of the B-29 Superfortress.

 
F-16 Fighting Falcon

Our Museum's F-16 Fighting Falcon before restoration.

Our Museum's F-16 Fighting Falcon after restoration.

The Museum successfully restored its F-16 Fighting Falcon in the fall of 2014. The aircraft once belonged to the ‘The TACOS’, the New Mexico Air National Guard 150th Fighter Wing. It was rescued from the Sandia National Laboratories Rocket Sled Track and restored for static display. The restoration included restoring the TACO trim and tail insignia to acknowledge the 50+ year legacy and historical significance of the TACOS. The restoration even included lighting the aircraft's navigation, vertical tail illumination and landing lights.

The TACOS were honored in the restoration of this airplane because of their legacy and contributions to our country. This division of the New Mexico Air National Guard has flown combat operations in Korea, Vietnam, Bosnia and Iraq and was mobilized and flew combat air patrol sorties throughout the United States following the attacks on September 11, 2011. The 150th Fighter Wing TACOS operated the F-16 from 1992 to 2003.

Restoration of this iconic aircraft was supervised by Restoration Project Coordinator, Major Jerry Hanks, USMC (Retired), and was completed with the help of volunteers from Sandia National Laboratories, Kirtland Air Force Base, Museum volunteers and members of the CNM Aviation Maintenance Technology program and Service-Learning program.

The Museum held a dedication ceremony for the newly restored F-16 on November 5, 2014. U.S. Senator Martin Heinrich; U.S. Senator Tom Udall; and Brigadier General Andrew Salas, Adjutant General for the New Mexico Air National Guard were present to publicly acknowledge the restoration as well as the legacy and historical significance of the TACOS.


USS James K. Polk Submarine Sail

Our Museum's submarine sail during restoration.

Our Museum's submarine sail after restoration.

The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History successfully completed the restoration of the iconic USS James K. Polk SSN 645 nuclear submarine sail in the fall of 2014.

This truly historic object, measuring 30 feet high by nine feet wide and weighing 53 tons, was acquired by the Museum in 1999, and restoration began in the spring of 2014. Named after the 11th president of the United States, the USS James K. Polk was commissioned as SSBN 645 in 1966. The James K Polk was later converted into an attack submarine and re-designated SSN 645, making for an illustrious 33-year career.

Under the supervision of Fernando, retired Process Engineer from Intel, and with help from Museum staff, volunteers and various partners, the submarine exhibit was a hub of activity throughout the summer of 2014. The completed submarine sail is now on permanent display in the Museum’s Heritage Park.

The Excitement

"Clever names for classified programs like Operation Redwing and Dominic, and Code Name Cherokee recall the gallant days of the Cold War and the nuclear arms race.  The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History's B-52B aircraft is an icon of that era and took part in those programs.  This remarkable and totally intact aircraft is the largest artifact at the Museum, and we are proud to restore it its former glory." - Restoration Project Coordinator, Major Jerry Hanks, USMC (Retired)

"The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History has been the proud caretaker of this historic airplane for more than 40 years. Our B-52B is emblematic of the Cold War and the arms race between the U.S. and USSR and is an incredibly important part of America's history." - Museum Director, Jim Walther

"This aircraft played a large part in the development of our nuclear weapons program and should be the cornerstone of Heritage Park." - Tom St. Aubin, Museum and Restoration Volunteer

"Every politician now is talking about restoring us to greatness.  But with our bomber, we mean it. It's history worth preserving." - Gary Hoe, Museum Docent

"Since starting it's service with the U.S. Air Force in 1955, no other bomber in the world has stood guard or has served as long as the B-52 bomber. For more than over half a century from the Cold War thru Vietnam, Desert Shield on to Desert Strom, Iraq Freedom on to Enduring Freedom. No plane has been feared by our enemies like the B-52. It's presence alone is able to strike fear into those who wish us harm. As quoted by the U.S. Air Force Chief of Staff when the bomber was first rolled out in 1954, 'The Long Rifle was the weapon of its day. Today this B-52 is the Long Rifle of the Air Age.'" - Jose Juvera, Museum Docent

The BUZZ
This campaign has been featured on hundreds of news platforms. Below are just a few examples of who is talking about us.
  • KRQE Channel 13, Albuquerque, NM
  • The Albuquerque Journal
  • NewsCastic
  • Aviation Pros
  • The Oklahoman
  • The Boston Globe
  • The Pilot News
  • The San Francisco Chronicle
  • The Miami Herald 
  • The Denver Post
  • Travel Weekly
  • The Journal Sentinel, Milwaukee, WI

Your Support/Our Gratitude 

The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History staff, board of trustees and volunteers all passionately believe in the mission of our Museum, and we know its past and future success depends on the generosity of our donors, volunteers and supporters.  Our heartfelt thanks go out to all of you.

Operation Preservation, The Campaign to Restore the Planes in Heritage Park is a massive undertaking, with the B-52B Stratofortress being only one of the five aircraft needing to be restored.  It would be impossible for the Museum to consider such a project without the confidence that generous donors will supply the bulk of the funding, and generous volunteers will supply the thousands of man-hours necessary to restore each aircraft. 

Thank you all.


Links

Information and Articles

  • The Story of the Boeing B-52 Stratofortress
  • History of the B-52
  • RB-52B Stratorfortess
  • Big Bang by Walter J. Boyne
  • B-52 Information
  • Serial Numbers
  • B-52B Stratofortress Restoration Project at NMNSH
  • B-52 Drops H-bomb - 1956 Universal Newsreel

Rewards
$5 Reward - Your name listed on the National Museum of Nuclear Science and History’s website as a member of the B-52B Restoration Team.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
$10 Reward - All of the $5 award, plus a Vintage postcard showing the B-52B Stratofortress, s/n 52-0013, on display at the National Atomic Museum, currently known as the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History, on Kirtland Air Force Base.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

$25 Reward - All of the $10 reward, plus a National Museum of Nuclear Science & History logo pin.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
$50 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus a red tote bag with the logo of the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
$100 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus a National Museum of Nuclear Science & History Deneen Pottery coffee mug, designed and hand and made in the USA.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

$250 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus two free passes to the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History and a VIP guided tour of the exterior of the B-52B Stratofortress, s/n 52-0013.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

$500 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus one pair of Aviator Flight Sunglasses.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

$1,000 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus your name listed as an Executive Producer in the B-52B Stratofortress s/n 52-0013 restoration and history video.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

$2,500 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus a framed vintage postcard signed by Restoration Project Coordinator, Major Jerry Hanks USMC (Ret), and Museum Director, Jim Walther.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

$5,000 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus a hand-built B-52B model, hand-painted to match the restored B-52B Stratofortress.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

$7,500 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus the Cockpit Navy G-1 Antique Lamb Leather Jacket.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

$10,000 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus one bombardier seat ticket for a ride on FIFI, the only flying B-29 Superfortress in the world. (To redeem this ticket for the best seat in the aircraft, go to the Commemorative Air Force website at www.AirPowerTour.org to determine FiFi's schedule. Then, meet Fifi and take the ride of your life.)

Risks and Challenges

The largest risk to this project is in not having the aircraft sufficiently restored so that it can be dedicated in the Fall of 2016. At a minimum, this means that the aircraft must be fully painted and the new windows put in place. For this to happen, the funding must be secured, the body work must be completed, the primer and paint applied, squadron and squadron and Air Force insignias painted and the windows purchased and installed.

Mitigation strategies that have been put in place include a schedule that includes time for unknowns such as weather and fluctuation in manpower. In addition, work to secure funds and manpower was started in mid 2015.

Overall, there is little risk that the project will not be completed. The restoration of the B-52B is the Museum's top priority in 2016, and the Museum has an excellent track record of completing aircraft projects. The largest, completed between 2009 and 2011, was the relocation of all aircraft and other Heritage Park exhibits from the Museum's first home, when it was located on Kirtland Air Force Base, to its current location. More recently, the Museum successfully completed the full restoration of the B-29 Superfortress, the F-16 Fighting Falcon and the USS James K. Polk SSN 645 nuclear submarine sail.


Thank you for your time and consideration!
story_txt:
Help Bring a Piece of History Back to Life
 The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History, a Smithsonian affiliated, non-profit Museum located in Albuquerque, New Mexico, is restoring its B-52B Stratofortress, serial number 52-0013.  She is one of only four B-models in the world on display for public viewing, the first to air drop a hydrogen bomb and the only B-52B left in existence that has dropped atomic weapons - all during testing.
This enormous restoration initiative is a special project within Operation Preservation, an ongoing campaign to repaint and refurbish the iconic aircraft in the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History’s nine-acre outdoor exhibit area, Heritage Park.
Our Museum's iconic B-52B has experienced the ravages of the southwestern weather, and we would like to ask for your support in paying for the surface preparation and painting of the exterior of the aircraft (a surface area of over 2/3 of an acre). By helping with this behemoth endeavor, your support will:



Celebrate the men and women who designed, built, maintained and flew every B-52 model since the 1950s to today's recent models.

Educate all generations on the historical significance of the B-52B Stratofortress.

Connect Museum visitors with an important part of America's history and provide them with an opportunity to experience a B-52B up close.






The total B-52B restoration cost is expected to be $120,000. Approximately 1/2 of this cost will be paid by this Indiegogo project. The money raised in this campaign will be used for the cosmetic restoration of the fuselage and wings. That is, to purchase the paint ($460) per gallon and primer ($300 per gallon), prepare the airplane's surface and then paint the fuselage and wings. This will also include painting the "Air Force Special Weapons Center" insignia on the starboard side and the "Air Force Systems Command" on the port side. To learn more about the B-52B surface area calculations and the cost of the paint for this project, please click here. 

If we exceed our campaign goal, we will work to add wheel-chair accessible pathways around the aircraft as well as lighting that will truly bring the airplane to life. In the instance we do not reach our entire goal of $60,000 with this campaign, Museum staff and volunteers will continue to push forward on the restoration. Painting an airplane of this size requires multiple work phases - including preparing the aircraft for paint, application of primer and application of paint - and we would focus on the phases that required less labor costs until sufficient funds are raised.
With a quickly approaching target completion date for the B-52B restoration of August, 2016, we ask that you please consider becoming a member of the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History's B-52B Restoration Team by making a donation through Indiegogo! As a part of the B-52B support team, you will personally help in the preservation of this iconic aircraft.


  About Our B-52B Stratofortress 

The B-52 Stratofortress is a
long-range, subsonic, jet-powered strategic bomber. Built by Boeing – with a
wingspan of 185 ft and weighing 420,000 lbs – B-52 airplanes
have been operated by the United States Air Force since the 1950s and the more
recent models are expected to serve continuously into the future. 


The first
B-52B  - one of only 50 ever made - was delivered to the Strategic Air Command (SAC) in June of 1955, and the B-model was the first in the B-52 series to actually serve with operational bomb wings in the Strategic Air Command. Over the
years, the aircraft has proved itself in combat and peace time readiness. The B-52B – the type of aircraft located at the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History – was the first truly operational version of the Stratofortress that
featured an enhanced reconnaissance capability and was fitted with a
bombing/navigation system, and they remained in service into the mid-1960s when
they were traded in for more modern B-52s.  


“Our B-52 at the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History is truly Albuquerque’s airplane,” said Jim Walther, Museum Director. “This airplane was delivered directly from Boeing to Kirtland in 1955, assigned to the Special Weapons Center at Kirtland Air Force Base, and it was never assigned to another Air Force base.”


The B-52B as it was displayed at the Museum when it was formerly known as the National Atomic Museum and was formerly located on Kirtland Air Force Base (1971-2001).


On April 29, 1955, Kirtland Air
Force Base (KAFB) received its first B-52B Stratofortress (our B-52B), s/n 52-0013. Major Jerome L. Blanchard accepted delivery of the aircraft at the
Boeing Plant in Seattle and piloted the aircraft to KAFB. All crew members were
from the 4925th Test Group. 
The aircraft was among the first
ten B-52Bs delivered to the Air Force. “Old 013” was assigned
to the Air Force Special Weapons Center at Kirtland Air Force Base. Our B-52B conducted many drop tests of inert
weapon shapes to explore weapons separation characteristics at release and to
gather ballistics data.
The aircraft participated in the Redwing Cherokee test, near the Bikini
Atoll.  On May 21, 1956, it became the
first B-52 to drop a live nuclear device and the first aircraft to drop a hydrogen bomb. Our B-52B  also participated in Operation Dominic which took place from April until
November 1962. Operation Dominic saw
the last atmospheric tests, including air drops of nuclear devices. In its
years of service, B-52B, s/n 52-0013, dropped over one dozen live nuclear devices in various
operations.
When the Limited Nuclear Test Ban treaty was signed in 1963, Albuquerque’s B-52B, s/n 52-0013, was removed from the roster and was later delivered to the Museum, formerly known as the National Atomic Museum, in 1971.

The B-52B Stratofortress:





Armament: Two
20mm Cannons, 43,000 lbs. of bombs.


Engines: EightPratt & Whitney J57-P-1W


Maximum Speed: 630
mph at 20,000 ft.


Cruising Speed: 525
mph


Range: 3,600
miles at combat weight. 7, 350 miles maximum ferry range.


Service Ceiling: 47,000 ft. at combat
weight.


Span: 185
ft.


Length: 156
ft. 7 in.


Weight: 420,000
lbs. gross


Crew: Six
to eight depending on mission.


Source: National
Museum of the United States Air Force.




Aerial view of B-52B Stratofortress, s/n 52-0013.


Our B-52B when it was assigned on May 21, 1956, to the Air Force Special Weapons Center for Operation Redwing (Cherokee) / TX-15-X1 Hydrogen Bomb test - Fred Island Air Force Base.

Our B-52B was briefly renamed Deterrent I for the Dominic series of nuclear tests in the Pacific in 1962. Shown here with a SAC crew from Sheppard Air Force Base, it had flown to the Pacific for the test series with a crew from Kirtland Air Force Base, which also participated in the tests, as did scientists from Sandia Corporation, the name at that time for Sandia National Laboratories.

    Who We Are




The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History is a Smithsonian Affiliate and is the nation's only congressionally chartered museum in its field. The Museum is nationally accredited though the American Alliance of Museum and is also a member of the Association of Science-Technology Centers. The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization.
The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History was established in 1969 as an intriguing place to learn the story of the Atomic Age, from early research of nuclear development through today’s peaceful uses of nuclear technology. The Museum strives to present, through permanent and changing exhibits and displays, the diverse applications of nuclear energy in the past, present and future along with the stories of the field’s pioneers.
This 30,000-sq-ft building and nine-acre outdoor exhibit area display artifacts from Geiger counters, historic medical devices and items from the Manhattan Project to vintage comic books, nostalgic toys and a B-29 Superfortress. The major interior exhibits include Nano, Pioneers of the Atom, Trinity and its Legacy, Hiroshima and Nagasaki, the Cold War, Energy Encounter, Nuclear Medicine, Radiation 101 and more. The Museum also hosts Little Albert’s Lab, an area where young, inquisitive minds can explore hands-on science activities.
Heritage Park, the Museum’s nine-acre outdoor exhibit area, is one of the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History’s most popular attractions. With its B-52B Stratofortress, B-29 Superfortress, B-47 Stratojet, F-105D Thunderchief, A-7 Corsair II and F-16 Fighting Falcon, the Museum’s collection is the largest aircraft collection for public viewing in the state of New Mexico.
The Museum’s mission is “to serve as America’s resource for nuclear history and science. The Museum presents exhibits and quality educational programs that convey the diversity of individuals and events that shape the historical and technical context of the nuclear age.” It is truly a place to learn, to imagine, to think and to draw your own conclusions.


Our Success Stories






Our Museum's B-29 Superfortress before restoration.

Our Museum's B-29 Superfortress after restoration.

The most current example of the Museum’s aircraft restoration work can be seen in last year’s Operation Preservation project that involved rescuing our B-29 Superfortress, one of only 17 complete aircraft of its kind left in existence.

Restoration of the B-29 began in April of 2015 under the supervision of Restoration Project Coordinator, Major Jerry Hanks, USMC (Retired), with help from Museum staff and volunteers and was funded by donations received from supporters and entities with personal ties to the Museum and the historic aircraft. The Museum also successfully raised over $44,000 through a Kickstarter campaign to pay for paint and primer.
Restoration included the B-29 receiving a new coat of primer and paint, bodywork to the aircraft, new cockpit windows and the vintage 509th Wing of the Strategic Air Command paint and trim. 
The Museum held a dedication ceremony on Tuesday, August 11, 2015, where dignitaries were present to publicly acknowledge the legacy and historical significance of the B-29 Superfortress. 

F-16 Fighting Falcon



Our Museum's F-16 Fighting Falcon before restoration.

Our Museum's F-16 Fighting Falcon after restoration.The Museum successfully restored its F-16 Fighting Falcon in the fall of 2014. The aircraft once belonged to the ‘The TACOS’, the New Mexico Air National Guard 150th Fighter Wing. It was rescued from the Sandia National Laboratories Rocket Sled Track and restored for static display. The restoration included restoring the TACO trim and tail insignia to acknowledge the 50+ year legacy and historical significance of the TACOS. The restoration even included lighting the aircraft's navigation, vertical tail illumination and landing lights.



The TACOS were honored in the restoration of this airplane because of their legacy and contributions to our country. This division of the New Mexico Air National Guard has flown combat operations in Korea, Vietnam, Bosnia and Iraq and was mobilized and flew combat air patrol sorties throughout the United States following the attacks on September 11, 2011. The 150th Fighter Wing TACOS operated the F-16 from 1992 to 2003.
Restoration of this iconic aircraft was supervised by Restoration Project Coordinator, Major Jerry Hanks, USMC (Retired), and was completed with the help of volunteers from Sandia National Laboratories, Kirtland Air Force Base, Museum volunteers and members of the CNM Aviation Maintenance Technology program and Service-Learning program.
The Museum held a dedication ceremony for the newly restored F-16 on November 5, 2014. U.S. Senator Martin Heinrich; U.S. Senator Tom Udall; and Brigadier General Andrew Salas, Adjutant General for the New Mexico Air National Guard were present to publicly acknowledge the restoration as well as the legacy and historical significance of the TACOS.


USS James K. Polk Submarine Sail



Our Museum's submarine sail during restoration.

Our Museum's submarine sail after restoration.The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History successfully completed the restoration of the iconic USS James K. Polk SSN 645 nuclear submarine sail in the fall of 2014.
This truly historic object, measuring 30 feet high by nine feet wide and weighing 53 tons, was acquired by the Museum in 1999, and restoration began in the spring of 2014. Named after the 11th president of the United States, the USS James K. Polk was commissioned as SSBN 645 in 1966. The James K Polk was later converted into an attack submarine and re-designated SSN 645, making for an illustrious 33-year career.Under the supervision of Fernando, retired Process Engineer from Intel, and with help from Museum staff, volunteers and various partners, the submarine exhibit was a hub of activity throughout the summer of 2014. The completed submarine sail is now on permanent display in the Museum’s Heritage Park.



The Excitement


"Clever names for classified programs like Operation Redwing and Dominic, and Code Name Cherokee recall the gallant days of the Cold War and the nuclear arms race.  The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History's B-52B aircraft is an icon of that era and took part in those programs.  This remarkable and totally intact aircraft is the largest artifact at the Museum, and we are proud to restore it its former glory." - Restoration Project Coordinator, Major Jerry Hanks, USMC (Retired)
"The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History has been the proud caretaker of this historic airplane for more than 40 years. Our B-52B is emblematic of the Cold War and the arms race between the U.S. and USSR and is an incredibly important part of America's history." - Museum Director, Jim Walther



"This aircraft played a large part in the development of our nuclear weapons program and should be the cornerstone of Heritage Park." - Tom St. Aubin, Museum and Restoration Volunteer



"Every politician now is talking about restoring us to greatness.  But with our bomber, we mean it. It's history worth preserving." - Gary Hoe, Museum Docent



"Since starting it's service with the U.S. Air Force in 1955, no other bomber in the world has stood guard or has served as long as the B-52 bomber. For more than over half a century from the Cold War thru Vietnam, Desert Shield on to Desert Strom, Iraq Freedom on to Enduring Freedom. No plane has been feared by our enemies like the B-52. It's presence alone is able to strike fear into those who wish us harm. As quoted by the U.S. Air Force Chief of Staff when the bomber was first rolled out in 1954, 'The Long Rifle was the weapon of its day. Today this B-52 is the Long Rifle of the Air Age.'" - Jose Juvera, Museum Docent


The BUZZ
This campaign has been featured on hundreds of news platforms. Below are just a few examples of who is talking about us.


KRQE Channel 13, Albuquerque, NM
The Albuquerque Journal
NewsCastic
Aviation Pros
The Oklahoman
The Boston Globe
The Pilot News
The San Francisco Chronicle
The Miami Herald 
The Denver Post
Travel Weekly
The Journal Sentinel, Milwaukee, WI




Your Support/Our Gratitude 




The National Museum of Nuclear Science & History staff, board of trustees and volunteers all passionately believe in the mission of our Museum, and we know its past and future success depends on the generosity of our donors, volunteers and supporters.  Our heartfelt thanks go out to all of you.
Operation Preservation, The Campaign to Restore the Planes in Heritage Park is a massive undertaking, with the B-52B Stratofortress being only one of the five aircraft needing to be restored.  It would be impossible for the Museum to consider such a project without the confidence that generous donors will supply the bulk of the funding, and generous volunteers will supply the thousands of man-hours necessary to restore each aircraft. 
Thank you all.





Links
Information and Articles





The Story of the Boeing B-52 Stratofortress

History of the B-52
RB-52B Stratorfortess
Big Bang by Walter J. Boyne
B-52 Information
Serial Numbers
B-52B Stratofortress Restoration Project at NMNSH
B-52 Drops H-bomb - 1956 Universal Newsreel





Rewards





$5 Reward - Your name listed on the National Museum of Nuclear Science and History’s website as a member of the B-52B Restoration Team.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
$10 Reward - All of the $5 award, plus a Vintage postcard showing the B-52B Stratofortress, s/n 52-0013, on display at the National Atomic Museum, currently known as the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History, on Kirtland Air Force Base.



-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

$25 Reward - All of the $10 reward, plus a National Museum of Nuclear Science & History logo pin.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
$50 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus a red tote bag with the logo of the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
$100 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus a National Museum of Nuclear Science & History Deneen Pottery coffee mug, designed and hand and made in the USA.



--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

$250 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus two free passes to the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History and a VIP guided tour of the exterior of the B-52B Stratofortress, s/n 52-0013.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
$500 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus one pair of Aviator Flight Sunglasses.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
$1,000 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus your name listed as an Executive Producer in the B-52B Stratofortress s/n 52-0013 restoration and history video.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
$2,500 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus a framed vintage postcard signed by Restoration Project Coordinator, Major Jerry Hanks USMC (Ret), and Museum Director, Jim Walther.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
$5,000 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus a hand-built B-52B model, hand-painted to match the restored B-52B Stratofortress.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
$7,500 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus the Cockpit Navy G-1 Antique Lamb Leather Jacket.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

$10,000 Reward - All of the $25 reward, plus one bombardier seat ticket for a ride on FIFI, the only flying B-29 Superfortress in the world. (To redeem this ticket for the best seat in the aircraft, go to the Commemorative Air Force website at www.AirPowerTour.org to determine FiFi's schedule. Then, meet Fifi and take the ride of your life.)
Risks and Challenges

The largest risk to this project is in not having the aircraft sufficiently restored so that it can be dedicated in the Fall of 2016. At a minimum, this means that the aircraft must be fully painted and the new windows put in place. For this to happen, the funding must be secured, the body work must be completed, the primer and paint applied, squadron and squadron and Air Force insignias painted and the windows purchased and installed.
Mitigation strategies that have been put in place include a schedule that includes time for unknowns such as weather and fluctuation in manpower. In addition, work to secure funds and manpower was started in mid 2015.
Overall, there is little risk that the project will not be completed. The restoration of the B-52B is the Museum's top priority in 2016, and the Museum has an excellent track record of completing aircraft projects. The largest, completed between 2009 and 2011, was the relocation of all aircraft and other Heritage Park exhibits from the Museum's first home, when it was located on Kirtland Air Force Base, to its current location. More recently, the Museum successfully completed the full restoration of the B-29 Superfortress, the F-16 Fighting Falcon and the USS James K. Polk SSN 645 nuclear submarine sail.


Thank you for your time and consideration!

story:
LANGUAGE APP

The importance of language education has become something that is disregarded and considered to be insignificant. Many Nigerian languages are threatened by extinction. Most of the youths are unable to speak their native dialects. They do not understand the importance of knowing and understanding ones’ origin. Often when asked where you are from the second question is more often than not “Do you speak the language?”, and I feel it is a shame when the response is no.

Language is a powerful symbol of one's identity. Much of the cultural, spiritual, and intellectual life of a people is experienced through language. This ranges from prayers, myths, ceremonies, poetry, oratory, and technical vocabulary to everyday greetings, conversational styles, humor, terms for habits, and behaviors. When a language is lost, all of this must be refashioned in the new language-with different words, sounds, and grammar- if it is to be kept at all. For these reasons, among others, it is very important to the community itself that its language survive.

PROBLEM:

There are many young Nigerians who can communicate excellently in English language but find it difficult to speak Igbo, Yoruba and other indigenous languages. These youths put themselves at a loss, because they rely on building relationships and understandings with foreign countries to improve the Nigerian economy when they are unable to understand their own culture. Instead of becoming leaders in their country, instead they become followers of the ways in western world, which will always keep them behind. In an increasingly globalized and interconnected world, Nigerian and their future workforce will be at a loss if they lack language skills and cultural awareness, missing out on opportunities to grow the economy by simply expecting everyone to speak English.

Although for many people it's important to know a major national or international language, that doesn't mean they must abandon their mother tongue. Children who grow up speaking two or more languages learn those languages just as well as children who grow up speaking only one language.

Another issue is that while the languages are endangered, many elders of many tribes still encourage tribalism. This is simply a segregation of a lost society, which is was the cause of the Nigerian civil war and must be stopped. If Nigeria is going to survive the test of time and advance in the direction of economic and industrial development, ethnic and tribal mentality must be eroded. I believe education ought to take precedence over tribal and ethnic alignment by broadening the mental horizon of ones perception about leadership as it relates to effective governance.

WHY I CREATED THE LANGUAGE APP:

I believe that multilingualism is a necessity especially in Nigeria. Whether viewed from the financial or social aspect, being able to communicate in various indigenous or foreign languages helps to make ‘real’ connection with people and opens up a number of opportunities. For businesses, having multilingual employees is essential to develop and sustain a strong footing in the economy. Therefore most companies look for candidates with language skills. As an employer, it will help encourage staff performance, improve customer services, and increase revenue for your company. Knowing more than one language means a person has more than one way of seeing things; they are a more able than not to think out of the box and be more innovative. I believe indigenous language education in Nigeria will increase the value put into tourism. Different tribes will be able to come as not just Igbo, Yoruba, Hausa, Efik but as Nigerians who see the value, beauty, and cultural diversity in their country and want to nurture it.

The Nigerian Language Policy on education was created to encourage the teaching and learning of indigenous and international languages (apart from English), which will achieve national unity. Nigerians will consider themselves as one instead of forming segregated groups based on tribe. However, the implementation of this policy has experienced numerous difficulties. Many schools cannot incorporate indigenous or foreign languages into their curriculum due to the lack of experienced teachers and the inability to recognize the importance of language education. Therefore indigenous and foreign languages, apart from English, have been abandoned. A better way of language education is required.

WHAT THE APP DOES:

The language learning app is a robust, colorful, fun, easy to understand and exciting language application that at this moment consists of 5 different languages preinstalled; Yoruba, Igbo, Hausa, English and French. Though more languages will be added based on customer demand, the focus as of now is on these 3 indigenous languages coupled with English and French because they are the more dominant of the many languages in Nigeria.

The application consist of various characters and voice command incorporated into the Rastvor Labs application in order to make it interactive ensuring that the individual using the app will not be bored.

The application was developed to make learning the thus stated languages more accessible. Learning pad can be used by the teachers as an aid during language classes and also it can be used by the students as a learning aid. Parents are encouraged to request for the specific languages that peeks their interest, if they do not want all 5. Using Rastvor Labs application will improve the unity amongst Nigerians and improve our understanding of one another. Through innovative technology, applied psychometrics, and a learning sciences team anchored by Rastvor Labs, we seek to empower a whole new generation of learners.

We want to establish a large regular customer base, and will therefore concentrate on elementary and high school all across Nigeria, which will be the dominant target market. This will establish a healthy, consistent revenue base to ensure stability of the business.

We have created a language app that is to be used by educational institutions and individuals to teach and learn the languages of other tribes apart from their own. Most cultures appreciate when someone considered an outsider understands and speaks the native tongue, it breaks down the barrier between people allowing the so called outsider be welcomed. This is what our language app will do to Nigeria.

The language app so far consist of five languages; Igbo, Yoruba, Hausa, English and French.

RISKS & CHALLENGES

There are no risks. The project will thrive on demand. We already have a number of schools and parents that are interested in purchasing the app.

WHAT WE NEED

In total, we need $7,000, for this Project, basically to pay the programmer, website designer, language experts and to for some Tabs for the testing and deployment of the application. Any other funding as they say will take care of itself. The breakdown is as follows:

  • We need $3000 to design the website and application interface
  • $500 will be required to pay for site hosting for five years. 
  • $3000 will go into the purchase of audio equipment: microphones and other acoustic tools, software and Tabs. A few of them are listed here:
      • MICROPHONE: An Audio Technica AT2020 USB Microphone: AT2020 Plus (or equivalent) 
      • HAND-HELD MICS:  
      • ACOUSTIC SHIELD:  
      • EARPHONES: equivalent studio-style headphone
      • Tablets

$500 will go to other incidentals (transportation for language experts, cost of photocopy, scanning, printing, internet, studio rentals, etc.) and also to purchase books ,and other helpful materials.

However, as much as $7000 will be most helpful, this drive is set up in such a way that even if we don't reach this entire goal, whatever is raised (especially anything above $1500) will go a long Way for the development of this App

Other Ways you can help

Another way to help would be to share this page with your friends and family. 

Tell the world about Rastvor Labs language app.

Please, help us make a fuss about the Rastvor Labs language app Indiegogo project.

Thanks

ABOUT ME

My name is Ogundiwin, Olusegun. I am currently 24 with a Bachelors of Science from the Bells University of Technology in computer science. 

Right from my undergraduate days I have been fascinated with languages, especially indigenous languages. Learning ancient tales and proverbs that have been sustained through the usage of language, also understanding the ways of life of a culture different from mine has always captivated me. One day while with some friends who did not understand or speak their language I realized that this has become a major problem in Africa. Where many of the youths have neglected their indigenous language because of the high importance given to the English language. Through the use of technology, I decide to created a language app for English as well as indigenous languages.

By the grace of God I founded a Technology company called Rastvor Labs. My company's aim is to give people a different type of solution. You can check our website out here: http://www.rastvorlabs.com/

MICROPHONE: An Audio Technica
       AT2020 USB Microphone: AT2020 Plus (or equivalent) 
HAND-HELD MICS:  
ACOUSTIC SHIELD:
        
EARPHONES: equivalent
       studio-style headphone 
Tablets


$500
will go to other incidentals (transportation for language experts, cost of
photocopy, scanning, printing, internet, studio rentals, etc.) and also to
purchase books ,and other helpful materials. 
However,
as much as $7000 will be most helpful, this drive is set up in such a way that
even if we don't reach this entire goal, whatever is raised (especially
anything above $1500) will go a long Way for the development of this AppOther Ways you can helpAnother way to help would be to share this page with your friends and family. Tell the world about Rastvor Labs language app.Please, help us make a fuss about the Rastvor Labs language app Indiegogo project.ThanksABOUT ME
My name is Ogundiwin, Olusegun. I am currently 24 with a Bachelors of Science from the Bells University of Technology in computer science. Right from my undergraduate days I have been fascinated with languages, especially indigenous languages. Learning ancient tales and proverbs that have been sustained through the usage of language, also understanding the ways of life of a culture different from mine has always captivated me. One day while with some friends who did not understand or speak their language I realized that this has become a major problem in Africa. Where many of the youths have neglected their indigenous language because of the high importance given to the English language. Through the use of technology, I decide to created a language app for English as well as indigenous languages.By the grace of God I founded a Technology company called Rastvor Labs. My company's aim is to give people a different type of solution. You can check our website out here: http://www.rastvorlabs.com/

story:
Safe Shelter Part 2

www.theroamingsanctuary.org

Thanks to all those that contributed to the success of the previous Safe Shelter for Tibetans in Nepal campaign.  The video shows just how well the project went and it is our gift to all contributors.

Nepal is home to several Tibetan refugee villages, that are spread throughout the country.  Our destination is Jampaling Settlement, which sits 45 minutes outside the small western city of Pokhara.  The village is home to approximately 750 Tibetan refugees.  

Safe shelter is still the priority.  Many families live with leaking roofs, crumbling walls or cannot afford shelter of their own.  Being refugees within Nepal, they have no legal citizenship, no rights and very few opportunities to earn income.  There is no indoor plumbing, no heat and very little reliable electricity.

We are returning October 7th, 2016, to Jampaling Settlement.

The Roaming Sanctuary would like to raise $5000.00 to provide 6 families with a safe, dry, clean dwelling.  As a result of the devastating  earthquake of 2015, there's been very little help for the Tibetan refugees.  The more we raise, the more families we can help.  Please help us help others, with your generous gift.

www.theroamingsanctuary.org




The Roaming Sanctuary will document each step of the project, and the website will provide updates on each phase as it occurs.  Our gift of total integrity is for everyone that contributes to The Roaming Sanctuary.  The gift of seeing the projects and the families that you've positively affected, and the love that you spread with your gift.  Thank you for your continued support.

www.theroamingsanctuary.com

story:
Short Summary

Who I am in a nutshell: 

I have a business background and a huge passion to teach children. I am also a single mom who wants to be there for her little one and at the same time provide for him.

I have a rich experience of over 7 years with children of all ages so I thought about combining my passion and my knowledge and start something great that would benefit me and my baby and at the same time other parents and their children.

As a parent (or as a single parent) I know how hard and expensive it is to find quality care for your littles ones, as parents we want to make sure that our little ones are growing and developing by getting the right education they need but without breaking our banks. I am raising money to create a preschool that offers a high quality fun artistic educational environment for the little one that is also affordable for their parents.

The preschool is going to be artistic based, where the children will learn through music, dance, paint, crafts and other activities. The program will also allow the children to learn through experience, and make everyday a learning adventure for them. It will have a lot of different rich activities throughout the day to keep the children engaged and motivated to learn and play. It will also have a language program to help children learn other languages at a very early stage.

It will have different workshops (theater, music, dance, art, and others). We will have a nice outdoor space to allow the kids to get fresh air and get dirty and a science lab. Kids will spend their day moving from a workshop to another. 

Also, the preschool will have a designated area for those parents who work from home, parents could sit and work while enjoying a cup of coffee while their kids play and interact with their peers.

With your contributions, we can make a difference and together we can build a better tomorrow! By contributing, you give a child the best gift that they could ever ask for, the gift of learning! 

What We Need & What You Get

After a deep market research, the start up costs would be as follow:

Educational Supplies (including e-learning)

$10,000.00

Furniture

$10,000.00

Renovations

$20,000.00

Administrative, licensing and legal fees

$5,000.00

Deposits

$7,000.00

Working Capital for 3 months

$40,000.00

Miscellaneous

$2,000.00

Indiegogo fee and processing fees

$6,720.00

Total

$100,720.00

As shown in the table above, we are dedicating a huge chunk of the budget to renovations, furniture and supplies, so that we can have top notch supplies for the kids. We are planning on renovating the space to fit the children's needs, by having a designated area for activities such as painting and another one for workshops such as dance, music and theater, and we will even have a science lab.

 
Now let's talk about what you will be getting as a thank you for your contribution.
 
For each contribution there is a little gift that goes with it as a token of our gratitude. 
 
Also, 20% of the capital will be opened to contributors, which will allow you to be our partner and receive a passive income for 12 months depending of your contribution, which means that your contribution will be an investment.
 
How would this work?
You will receive a % of the profit (dividends) depending on the amount of your contribution, starting after the 1st trimester of the opening (in any given business, the profits are not always expected in the first three months so to maximize your income, the dividends won't be distributed until that profit grows a little bit). 
You will also have a chance to participate in the preschool's forum and Page to give ideas and suggestions  about the overall preschool. 
 
The Impact

This campaign is not only to help me and help other kids but it is also an investment for you.

Sure, your contributions will allow me to realize my dream by working and taking care of my little one. It would also allow lots of children learn and grow. But it will help YOU as well make a little passive income depending on your contribution. 

In addition and most importantly this project will allow me and my child to start fresh and start a happy chapter in our lives. Every parent has big dreams and big hopes for their kids and hope for the day when they proudly say "that's my kid!", I do too. But most importantly I want my kid to be proud of me as well, I want to be his inspiration and I can't be unless I try extra hard to make things happen for us, and this is my first step towards making my child proud of me.

In addition, your contribution will also help save other kids and women in difficult situations, a % of our profits will be dedicated to helping empower single moms especially those who were in abusive situation, there will be a program to help them go back to school and help them find the right jobs for them. We will also have scholarships available for kids with limited resources.

Risks & Challenges

Like every business out there, there is always a risk, however that risk is somehow lowered with a lot of hard work and determination. 

I am 100% confident and positive that this project would be a success because I am more than willing to work extra hard to make it happen. I am also confident in my skills and experience and know that I will be able to make this project a little heaven for the little ones.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, we would still appreciate your support please:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Share it with your friends and family!
  • And if there is anything else that you can do to help us make happen, please do share :)

Thank you very much!

story:
Keeping your roots alive!

My name is Gbemisola Isimi and I am the founder and CEO of CultureTree Ltd.

CultureTree is on a mission and that mission is to preserve and teach children indigenous Nigerian languages. Without sounding overly dramatic, it has become increasingly obvious that we need to claim back our birth right and that is the language of our forefathers. We can be proud of our children’s good English and pronunciation but we must not let our mother tongue become a foreign language to them. We should be even prouder when they can not only understand our language but also speak it proficiently.

Many Nigerian parents are on-board and are making efforts to teach and expose their children to their mother tongue but for various different reasons the practicalities of introducing a second language at home can be akin to playing darts with spaghetti (if you catch my drift). That is where CultureTree comes in!

Our method is simple. We make the language learning process a fun, interactive and positive experience. Children are more likely to be curious when presented with songs, rhymes, stories and games and therefore are more likely to learn and retain knowledge.

We launched a YouTube channel aptly named ‘CultureTreeTV Yoruba’ with 2 animated Yoruba Nursery Rhyme videos on 1st April 2016. To date, this channel now has 5 animated Yoruba Nursery Rhyme videos and one read-aloud picture story. The channel has met with great approval and has gained over 200 subscribers in a very short space of time.

I've also been featured in: 

·  The Guardian Nigeria - http://m.guardian.ng/guardian-woman/not-much-is-being-done-to-promote-nigerian-languages/

·  A popular Nigerian blog BellaNaija - http://www.bellanaija.com/2016/04/yoruba-nursery-rhymes-on-youtube-yes-please-preserving-nigerian-culture-with-gbemisola-isimi-of-culturetreetv/

·  Yorubakids website - http://www.yorubakids.com/new-fun-content/yoruba-nursery-rhymes-culture-tree-tv

·  A video for the BBC on Identity - http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-36149011

Our Plan

We realise that there are over 500 indigenous languages spoken by Nigerians all over the world and while we would love to teach all of these, it is a mammoth task so we will start with the three main ones; Yoruba, Hausa and Igbo.

For all three languages, we want to produce:

·  An iOS and android children’s language App with flashcards, games, original stories (read-to-me, read-aloud and auto-play options) and learning activities.

·  Twelve animated Nursery Rhyme videos (the more money we raise, the more videos we can produce).

·  Read-aloud storybooks on the YouTube channel (we can continue indefinitely to produce a story every fortnight with the equipment and software we hope to purchase detailed below).

·  A comprehensive CultureTree website.

Our educational materials will cover all early learning skills and developmental milestones for children, namely:

- First concepts
- Nature and Animals
- Imagination and Creativity
- Building friendships
- Songs and Rhymes
- Guessing Games
- Activities

What We Need

As mentioned earlier, we have already made great strides in starting the project but it has been totally self-funded thus far.

To make the above plan a reality, we have calculated that we need £15,000.

The creators, producers & musicians are donating their time. Therefore these funds will be used only for production costs, including the animation, music recording studio time, music production, filming, editing, recording equipment and app development.

The breakdown is as follows:

·  App development - £3500

·  Freelance Translator fee for all 3 languages - £1500

·  3D animation for the Nursery Rhymes cost £300 each. Twelve videos will cost £3,600

·  Music Production and studio recording time - £110 per song. Twelve Nursery Rhymes will cost £1,320

·  Canon 70D SLR Camera - £722 (http://bit.ly/27QQqlX)

·  Rode Camera Microphone - £146.95 (http://amzn.to/1RkRYZk)

·  Editing equipment:

o  Mac Pro 13 inch with Retina display - £1,230.60 (http://apple.co/244HXXJ)

o  Adobe Final Cut Pro X - £229.99 (http://apple.co/25i2ZYE)

·  Website development is £1,500 (web domain already purchased at www.culturetree.co.uk). The .com domain was already taken.

·  HP Printer - £149.00 (http://bit.ly/1sxYmIh)

·  The rest of the funds (approx. £1,100) will go towards purchasing a collection of storybooks and other miscellaneous costs.

Please help spread the word, share on your social media handles and make some noise about the campaign on our behalf. We truly appreciate all contributions, whether big or small.

story:
Short Summary

Hello, My name is Donna Ghanney, CEO of Kingdom Empowerment, Inc.

Kingdom Empowerment, Inc. was established to educate individuals in the areas of coaching, mentoring, leadership, business and nonprofit startups, budgeting and finances, health, spiritual growth, trafficking and many other areas in support of providing social, mental and physical sustainability globally.

I was inspired to empower individuals to be successful when visiting Ghana West Africa in the Central Region in 2012. I visited an area called the Zongo and was able to see first hand how young ladies from 12 and up were given over into marriage or trafficking. The underlying area and cause for this being acceptable was poverty conditions, and living in an environment that deems it acceptable. Later, when I returned to America, and walked in impoverished areas, I learned that the same stigma existed here. This provoked me to develop programs to educate, empower, and equip individuals globally to be successful in every area of their lives. Our programs are designed to encourage and motivate individuals to allow transformation to take place in their lives.  We also are inspired to help them continue the pace after the seminar by providing one on one coaching, tools, and resources to help them continue the pace. Our goals is to see that every seed that is planted is utilized and maximized to its greatest extent when we provide any financial support to help women remain sustainable in their vision.

What We Need & What You Get

We need monies to continue the development of high-end technologies to support our educational initiatives.

We need monies to help individuals who would like to attend high end seminars to be able to attend the events for free.

We need monies to fund facilitation, materials, and to bring the necessary speakers to support the needs of the women in each community we visit with seminars.

Individuals, Business Owners, Vendors and Advertisers will receive recognition for their contributions.  You are allowed to share your logos, business cards, and other materials with the women with provide the seminars to.

My main expenses for this project include:

* Airfare (Texas, Oklahoma, Florida, Atlanta, Ghana, Nigeria)

* Lodging (Texas, Oklahoma, Florida, Atlanta, Ghana, Nigeria)

* Translator fees

*  Visa fees

* Facilitation for 5 events (Texas, Oklahoma, Florida, Atlanta, Ghana)

* Basic expenses while in (Texas, Oklahoma, Florida, Atlanta, Ghana)

* Technologies

* Speaker Engagement Fees (Subject Matter Experts)

* Materials, packaging, and shipping cost.

To cover these preliminary costs I need $125,000.  Anything raised in addition to my goal will be used for toward 2017 Seminars.

We truly appreciate your help in creating this unique opportunity to empower and equip women globally in education, spiritually, and social transformation. Your help is going towards the movement needed to fundamentally change the way we transform social development, education, and women’s empowerment—three of the areas We are incredibly passionate about.

No amount is to small. Everything counts just as much as your heart will beat each second!

The Impact

We believe that an impact on 5,000 women can spread like a wildfire and have a trickling effect on the family as a whole.

It is my fervent hope that your sponsorship, will begin to pave the way for women to experience authentic empowerment through cultivating a more spiritual and experiential perspective for empowerment in all areas of their lives, not merely within America, but globally.  

  • We have already started the race to achieve our goals by using monies collected through our Jewelry4AQueen Collection @ http://www.opensky.com/jewelry4aqueen.  This has enabled us to reach women thus far. However we need more help. We are receiving the cries for more. Women are thirsting for more real insights and to be motivated to succeed.
  • We have grown since we first started from reaching 40 persons in our very first seminar to reaching 3,280 to date successfully. We reach individuals via our digital magazine, radio, and various social media channels as well.

Risks & Challenges

Our risk and challenges are minimal at present.

  • We will need to overcome coordination of facilitation of seminars and finding the most less expensive establishments.
  • We will need to organize subject matter experts that are local as much as possible to reduce the cost of travel.
  • We will need to take consideration of mass production of materials to reduce the expenses that may incur.
  • Our plan for solving these problems in planning the events 60 days out prior to each event; coordinate team, manage and implement accordingly; monitor, control, and mitigate risks that may occur.
  • We will need to maximize our potential with automated and cloud technologies and phone apps to support a global environment.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some of you may not be able to support our social cause, and we sincerely understand.  However you can help us in kind by sharing our social cause with others.

  • How, use the Indiegogo share tools to share on your Facebook, Twitter, and other pages!

And that's all there is to it.

My main expenses for this project include:
* Airfare (Texas, Oklahoma, Florida, Atlanta, Ghana, Nigeria)
* Lodging (Texas, Oklahoma, Florida, Atlanta, Ghana, Nigeria)
* Translator fees
*  Visa fees
* Facilitation for 5 events (Texas, Oklahoma, Florida, Atlanta, Ghana)
* Basic expenses while in (Texas, Oklahoma, Florida, Atlanta, Ghana)
* Technologies
* Speaker Engagement Fees (Subject Matter Experts)
* Materials, packaging, and shipping cost.
To cover these preliminary costs I need $125,000.  Anything raised in addition to my goal will be used for toward 2017 Seminars.
We truly appreciate your help in creating this unique opportunity to empower and equip women globally in education, spiritually, and social transformation. Your help is going towards the movement needed to fundamentally change the way we transform social development, education, and women’s empowerment—three of the areas We are incredibly passionate about.
No amount is to small. Everything counts just as much as your heart will beat each second!

The Impact

We believe that an impact on 5,000 women can spread like a wildfire and have a trickling effect on the family as a whole.
It is my fervent hope that your sponsorship, will begin to pave the way for women to experience authentic empowerment through cultivating a more spiritual and experiential perspective for empowerment in all areas of their lives, not merely within America, but globally.  

We have already started the race to achieve our goals by using monies collected through our Jewelry4AQueen Collection @ http://www.opensky.com/jewelry4aqueen.  This has enabled us to reach women thus far. However we need more help. We are receiving the cries for more. Women are thirsting for more real insights and to be motivated to succeed.
We have grown since we first started from reaching 40 persons in our very first seminar to reaching 3,280 to date successfully. We reach individuals via our digital magazine, radio, and various social media channels as well.


Risks & Challenges
Our risk and challenges are minimal at present.

We will need to overcome coordination of facilitation of seminars and finding the most less expensive establishments.
We will need to organize subject matter experts that are local as much as possible to reduce the cost of travel.
We will need to take consideration of mass production of materials to reduce the expenses that may incur.
Our plan for solving these problems in planning the events 60 days out prior to each event; coordinate team, manage and implement accordingly; monitor, control, and mitigate risks that may occur.
We will need to maximize our potential with automated and cloud technologies and phone apps to support a global environment.


Other Ways You Can Help
We understand that some of you may not be able to support our social cause, and we sincerely understand.  However you can help us in kind by sharing our social cause with others.
How, use the Indiegogo share tools to share on your Facebook, Twitter, and other pages!
And that's all there is to it.

story:
KPI (Kenioto Permaculture Institute)is a project of an ecolodge integrated with a Permaculture farm and institute in Kenioto, Kedougou Senegal.


The aim of this project is to buy a former hunting camp of 2.5 hectares and transform it into a Permaculture Farm Institute coupled with an eco lodge.

The buying has already started with the solicitor of Kedougou and we need your support to create this farm-institute and teach Permaculture and agro ecology to hundreds of people from Senegal, neighboring countries and people from all over the world.

To buy this hunting camp and transform it into a Permaculture Farm Institute we need 40000 USD

You can contribute between  10 and 25 US Dollars

Each of these  contributors will receive a customized letter of thanks from Kédougou

You can contribute US Dollar 50

Each US Dollar 50 contributor will have his name on KPI website

You can contribute US Dollar 100

 Each US Dollar 100 contributor will have his name Graved on the Permaculture Institute walls and website and will have a 10 % discount for the first PDC Permaculture Design Course in Kénioto in summer 2017

story:
Project Women in Red (ou PWR) sera la toute première pépinière d’entreprises innovantes dédiée aux jeunes femmes du Cameroun : bureaux, accompagnement individuel de Aà Z (du montage de business plan à la recherche de financement), services mutualisés (courrier, moyens de reprographie, réception des appels téléphoniques…), espaces communs (cafétéria, accueil…), événements, échanges avec les acteurs du monde économique local, formations sur les grands thèmes de la vie de l’entreprise… 

Motivant, innovant, adapté et pratique, PWR est un projet 100% porté par l'association VertRougeJeunes, déjà organisatrice de plusieurs événements autour de l’entrepreneuriat jeune. PWR sera basé à Yaoundé, Cameroun.

La vocation même de Project Women in Red est de révéler le potentiel de chaque jeune femme et lui donner confiance en elle. Le rouge (red) a été choisi à dessein, car cette couleur est affiliée à la vie. Le rouge représente, en termes de besoins essentiels, le besoin de chaleur, de survie, mais aussi le besoin d’être actif et de travailler.

Associez-vous à cette initiative positive et impactante pour 10 jeunes femmes par an, qui seront ainsi mieux armées pour prendre leur destin en main !

Le principe de sélection pour bénéficier d’un accompagnement sur 12 mois est simple : nous allons confronter de jeunes femmes porteures d’un projet d’entreprise innovant (tous secteurs d’activité confondus) à un jury qui va les questionner et les challenger.

Faites de Project Women in Red la pépinière qui fera pousser de véritables championNEs de l’entrepreneuriat africain (le continent en a besoin !) et impliquez-vous davantage dans cette aventure en devenant par exemple membre du jury de sélection.

Merci de votre soutien !!!

A quoi va servir le financement ?

Mener à fond une telle initiative, qui est avant tout associative et 100% privée (et du coup totalement indépendante) demande une bonne dose d'énergie et, il faut bien l'avouer, un peu (beaucoup) d'argent. D'autant plus que nous voulons bien faire les choses et sortir des sentiers battus.

Nous avons notamment besoin de cet argent pour :

  • Régler 12 mois de loyer histoire d'avoir l’esprit tranquille et nous concentrer sur l’essentiel
  • Effectuer des travaux d'aménagement afin que l’entrepreneuriat soit vécu autrement (non pas comme une malédiction :-)
  • Souscrire à des offres de télécommunications de base (WIFI illimité, forfait téléphonique)
  • Acquérir des meubles pratiques et modernes
  • Acheter du matériel technologique utile et ultraperformant
  • Former et rémunérer une équipe d’encadreurs jeune et hyper motivée
  • Favoriser l’embauche d’un nouveau permanent pour prendre en charge le quotidien du lieu
  • Supporter pendant un an, les frais de fonctionnement, notamment pour la recherche de partenaires stratégiques et financiers
  • Organiser des événements au cours desquels nos entrepreneures en herbe pourront se mêler à des entrepreneurs confirmés
  • Et de manière générale, pour équilibrer le budget de ce joli projet !

A votre bon cœur !

L’équipe PWR.

À propos du porteur de projet :

Créée en 2014 au Cameroun à l’initiative d’Alexandra Ondoua (elle-même entrepreneurE), VertRougeJeunes est une association à but non lucratif qui promeut l’autonomisation, le leadership et l’entrepreneuriat des jeunes.

story: I seek to better understand the principal causes of migration and to demonstrate solidarity with migrants and their families, as well as the grassroots movements that are organizing to create social and economic alternatives. This fact finding mission will also investigate the extent and impact of the US governments new push to militarize the borders among El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Mexico.

story:
If you are supporting us, now you are also supporting the Illatosi út dog shelter!

http://ebtelep.hu/
08.03.2016.


Short Summary


  • The main organizer of the con. is Risley Addix. I have been into this lifestyle since I was fourteen and I have learned many things abroad and would like to spread the knowledge here in Hungary, but we need your support in order to be able to finance great, foreign presenters.
  • This is a very important event for me, because I would like my fellow kinkster to be able to have safe, kinky activites.
  • The event is going to take place in an exclusive environment, with a nice swimming pool, jacuzzi and many BDSM tools and furnitures!


What We Need & What You Get


  • We need 5.000 dollars in order to be able to cover all the expenses of our foreign presenters (flight, accomodation, food).
  • If you support us (with anything) you will get a free guided tour in Budapest!
  • If you support us with over 50 dollars, a special pin of the I. Hungarian BDSM Con. 
  • If you support us with over 100 dollars, you will recieve a handmade, Hungarian BDSM toy.


Risks & Challenges


  • Since Hungary is not a very rich country, we need your help for this important event to happen.
  • I trust the International Kinky Community, I know many of You, and I know, that you are very kind and helpful. This is why I have started this campaign.

Other Ways You Can Support us


  • If you cannot support us financially, please share this with your fellow, kinky friends!
  • You may also come and help us at the venue of the conference.
Thank you for your support!
